name: sulfate pulp production, from eucalyptus, bleached | sulfate pulp, bleached | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/18691/documentation

This dataset represents an aggregation of the Latin American production of Elemental Chlorine Free (ECF) and Totally Chlorine Free (TCF) kraft pulp, obtained from eucalyptus wood in 2020. Industry data was used which was provided by the European Pulp Industry Sector (EPIS). The used values are a weighted average of all corresponding pulp mills. The represented technology is considered state of the art for a Latin American average.;PULP is a wood-based raw material to make different paper, board and other products. The pulp, or fibers from the wood are separated in a kraft cooking process in a so-called fiber line. In a recovery line, the chemicals used in the cooking process are recovered to be used again and energy is produced. The third process is effluent treatment where gaseous and liquid discharges to the environment are continuously minimized and monitored.;MAIN END USES FOR MARKET PULP • Tissue (toilet paper) • Graphic papers • Specialty products • Packaging • Fluff pulp • Viscose • CMC etc. ;PRODUCTS GENERATED IN THE PULPING PROCESS include  electricity and heat;CAPACITIES World’s total market capacities for softwood kraft pulp, hardwood kraft pulp, and eucalyptus kraft pulp were 28.9 million tons, 15 million tons, and 26.2 million tons, respectively.;SPECIES Softwood pulp is made from coniferous trees, most typically from different species of pine and spruce. Hardwood pulp is made from non-coniferous trees, in Nordic countries primarily of birch. Eucalyptus hardwood pulp is made exclusively of eucalyptus species.;CHARACTERISTICS Softwood fibers are long and slender and are used to give the paper and board products their strength properties. Hardwood fibers are short and can be rounder and their number per gram of pulp is much larger; they give the end product its smoothness, softness and optical properties like opacity (that you cannot see through the paper).

This activity starts with the transport of the pulpwood to the pulp factory. The pulpwood input has an activity links to the supplying activity and is therefore not supplied via market dataset

The process includes transports to the pulp mill, wood handling, chemical pulping and bleaching, drying process, energy production on-site, recovery cycles of chemicals and internal waste water treatment. The following air emissions were reported in the study: CO2 (fossil and biogenic), SOx (as SO2), NOx, TRS (as S), SO2 (reported as S), and Dust (unspecified). Next to these key emissions, additional emissions from on-site energy production from external and internal fuels were calculated, using emission profiles from ecoinvent combustion processes. Internal biogenic fuels are represented by the calculated emissions but do not have the corresponding fuel input from technosphere, because they are supplied from within the system boundaries. The amounts of internal fuels used in the process are: Biogas (14.17 MJ/t), Bark (314.06 MJ/t), Black liquor (12745.89 MJ/t), Sludge (3.65MJ/t), Hydrogen (96.48 MJ/t), Methanol (16.51 MJ7t), Biomass (2950.125 MJ/t). Black liquor and sludge were not included in the emissions calculations because no specific emission profiles, e.g. for the black liquor recovery process, were available. Emissions from these internal energy generation processes are therefore only reflected in the key emission factors provided by the industry, other emissions constitute a data gap. The activity ends when the kraft pulp is ready to be sold.
category: C:Manufacturing/17:Manufacture of paper and paper products/170:Manufacture of paper and paper products/1701:Manufacture of pulp, paper and paperboard

processDocumentation.timeDescription: Data gathered in 2021 and represents data of 2020 values. Recent technology valid for the upcoming years.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Average Latin America technology in 2020 of kraft pulp production of ECF and TCF pulp
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription: Industry data provided key emission factors for CO2 (biogenic), SOx (as SO2), NOx, TRS (as S), SO2 (reported as S), Dust (unspecified). Additional air emissions resulting from on-site energy production, i.e. the combustion of fuels, were calculated based on industrial heating datasets from the ecoinvent database. The following ecoinvent combustion processes were used to estimate additional air emissions: Heavy fuel oil: "heat production, heavy fuel oil, at industrial furnace 1MW”, Diesel: "heat production, light fuel oil, at industrial furnace 1MW”, Natural gas, biogas, non-condensable gases and methanol: "heat production, natural gas, at industrial furnace >100kW” , Biofuels, wood and bark: "heat production, wood chips from industry, at furnace 1000kW. CO2, CO and CH4 emissions from biogas and methanol were modelled as non-fossil.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription: Weighted average of 10 mills providing 58% of the Latin America capacity of bleached kraft pulp from eucalyptus.

flow.name: sulfate pulp, bleached
flow.category: C:Manufacturing/17:Manufacture of paper and paper products/170:Manufacture of paper and paper products/1701:Manufacture of pulp, paper and paperboard

exchanges.description: Estimation based on fuel input data and emission factors from corresponding ecoinvent fuel combustion datasets (see "Extrapolations" comment). Apart from external fuel inputs, internal fuels such as bark, black liquor, and sludge are generated during the process and supply considerable amounts of process energy. Internal biogenic fuels are represented by the calculated emissions but do not have the corresponding fuel input from technosphere, because they are supplied from within the system boundaries. The amounts of internal fuels used in the process are: Biogas (14.1732 MJ/t), Bark (314.0627 MJ/t), Black liquor (12745.8861 MJ/t), Sludge (3.6497 MJ/t), Hydrogen (96.4795 MJ/t), Methanol (16.5055 MJ/t), Biomass (2937.3263 MJ/t), Biomass (BAGASSE) (2.0643 MJ/t), Biomass (CHIPS) (10.7341 MJ/t). Black liquor, and sludge were not included in the emissions calculations because no specific emission profiles, e.g. for the black liquor recovery process, were available. Emissions from these internal energy generation processes are therefore only reflected in the key emission factors provided by the industry, other emissions constitute a data gap.

The amounts of internal fuels used in the process are: Biogas (14.1732 MJ/t), Bark (314.0627 MJ/t), Black liquor (12745.8861 MJ/t), Sludge (3.6497 MJ/t), Hydrogen (96.4795 MJ/t), Methanol (16.5055 MJ/t), Biomass (2937.3263 MJ/t), Biomass (BAGASSE) (2.0643 MJ/t), Biomass (CHIPS) (10.7341 MJ/t). Black liquor, and sludge were not included in the emissions calculations because no specific emission profiles, e.g. for the black liquor recovery process, were available. Emissions from these internal energy generation processes are therefore only reflected in the key emission factors provided by the industry, other emissions constitute a data gap.

Apart from external fuel inputs, internal fuels such as bark, black liquor, and sludge are generated during the process and supply considerable amounts of process energy. Internal biogenic fuels are represented by the calculated emissions but do not have the corresponding fuel input from technosphere, because they are supplied from within the system boundaries. The amounts of internal fuels used in the process are: Biogas (14.1732 MJ/t), Bark (314.0627 MJ/t), Black liquor (12745.8861 MJ/t), Sludge (3.6497 MJ/t), Hydrogen (96.4795 MJ/t), Methanol (16.5055 MJ/t), Biomass (2937.3263 MJ/t), Biomass (BAGASSE) (2.0643 MJ/t), Biomass (CHIPS) (10.7341 MJ/t). Black liquor, and sludge were not included in the emissions calculations because no specific emission profiles, e.g. for the black liquor recovery process, were available. Emissions from these internal energy generation processes are therefore only reflected in the key emission factors provided by the industry, other emissions constitute a data gap.

The amounts of internal fuels used in the process are: Biogas (14.1732 MJ/t), Bark (314.0627 MJ/t), Black liquor (12745.8861 MJ/t), Sludge (3.6497 MJ/t), Hydrogen (96.4795 MJ/t), Methanol (16.5055 MJ/t), Biomass (2937.3263 MJ/t), Biomass (BAGASSE) (2.0643 MJ/t), Biomass (CHIPS) (10.7341 MJ/t). Black liquor, and sludge were not included in the emissions calculations because no specific emission profiles, e.g. for the black liquor recovery process, were available. Emissions from these internal energy generation processes are therefore only reflected in the key emission factors provided by the industry, other emissions constitute a data gap.
